Description:
Removing unwanted tissue or foreign materials from various body surfaces,
                including mechanical tooth cleaning and/or gloss improvement.
Taking up water- and/or oil-soluble (dissolved or finely dispersed) substances.
Tending to unite/bind/bond surfaces together.

Preventing or relieving the symptoms of seborrhea and/or seborrheic dermatitis,
                including dandruff.
Helping control sebum production.

Preventing agglomeration of particulate solids into lumps or hard masses
                (cohesive cake), thus allowing free flow of particles.
Preventing and or inhibiting the corrosion of the packaging material.

Suppressing foam during manufacturing or reducing the tendency of finished
                products to generate foam.
Preventing and/or slowing down microbial growth.
Inhibiting reactions promoted by oxygen, thus avoiding oxidation and rancidity.
Reducing perspiration.
Helping protect against plaque.

Preventing and/or reducing static electricity by neutralising electrical charge
                on surfaces.
Contracting and/or tightening the skin.

Providing adhesive properties during and after compression in cosmetic tablets
                and/or cakes.
Bleaching or lightening the shade of hair and/or skin.

Stabilising the pH of an aqueous medium in a narrow range even if an acid or
                base is added. Altering and/or maintaining a cosmetic product's pH at the desired level.

Non-reactive (chemically inert), solid ingredients that dilute other solids
                and/or increase the volume of cosmetic products.

Forming complexes with metal ions which could affect the stability and/or
                appearance of cosmetics.
Helping to keep the body surface clean.

Exclusively or mainly intended to colour the cosmetic product, the body as a
                whole or certain parts thereof, by absorption or reflection of visible light; (precursors of oxidative
                hair colorants shall be deemed colorants). All authorised colorants are substances in the positive list
                of Annex IV to the Cosmetics Regulation 1223/2009.

Rendering cosmetics unpalatable. Mostly added to cosmetics containing ethyl
                alcohol to make it unsuitable for ingestion.

Reducing and/or eluminating unpleasant odour. Contributing against the formation
                of malodour on body surfaces.

Breaking down the the mechanical strength of hair fibers so that they can be
                removed by mild scraping/rubbing.

Reducing or eliminating hair intertwining due to hair surface alteration or
                damage and, thus, helping combing.

Facilitating the dispersion of solids in liquids. They function primarily by
                coating the solid through the process of adsorption, thus changing the surface characteristic of the
                suspended solid.

Helping the process of emulsification and improving emulsion stability and
                shelf-life.

Applied to the skin, and stripped off quickly to remove hair. With epilation the
                entire hair is removed from the follicle, whereas with depilation the hair is removed only to the
                surface of the skin.

Initiating and/or accelerating removal of the layers of dead skin cells from the
                skin surface.

Conditioning and enhancing the appearance of eyelashes. Improving the gloss or
                sheen of eyelashes, coating the eyelash hair to increase the appearance of its diameter and length, or
                helping with the separation of the eyelash hair.
Producing (upon application) a continuous film on the skin, hair or nails.
Imparting taste and/or flavour to a cosmetic product.

Traping numerous small bubbles of air or other gas within a small volume of
                liquid by modifying the surface tension of the liquid.

Imparting an odour or taste. Creating a perceivable pleasant smell and/or
                masking a bad smell.
is any inert ingredient used to create bulk, texture or lubrication.

Giving the consistency of a gel (a semi-solid preparation with some elasticity)
                to a liquid preparation.

Enhancing the appearance and feel of hair. Leaving the hair easy to comb,
                supple, soft and shiny and/or imparting volume, lightness, gloss, texture, etc.

Imparting color to hair. Hair dyeing preparations may be temporary,
                semi-permanent, permanent, depending on the length of time the colorant remains on the hair.
Permitting physical control of hair style.

Modifying the chemical structure of the hair, allowing it to be set in the style
                required (permanent waves or hair straightening).
Retaining and/or preserving the moisture in a product during use.
Helping to eliminate the dead cells of the stratum corneum.
Protecting the cosmetic product from deterioration effects of light.

Helping to break down lipids, proteins, and polysaccharides into smaller
                components, usually by the action of enzymes.
Increasing the water content of the skin and keeping it soft and smooth.

Improving and/or enhancing the cosmetic characteristics of the nail
                (moisturizing, increasing sheen, reducing brittleness and flaking, etc.).
Forming a hard structure that resembles the nail plate.
No function currently reported
Preventing and/or slowing down the evaporation of water from the skin surface.
Reducing transparency or translucency of cosmetics.

Providing cosmetic effects to the oral cavity, e.g. cleansing, deodorising,
                protecting.

Changing the chemical nature of another ingredient by adding oxygen (or removing
                hydrogen).
Imparting a nacreous appearance to cosmetics.
Used for perfume and aromatic raw materials.

Softening and making supple synthetic polumers that otherwise could not be
                easily deformed, spread or worked out.

Exclusively or mainly intended to inhibit the development of micro-organisms in
                the cosmetic product. All authorised preservatives are substances in the positive list of Annex V to the
                Cosmetics Regulation 1223/2009.

Generating pressure in an aerosol pack, expelling contents when the valve is
                opened. Some liquefied propellants can act as solvents.

Changing the chemical nature of another ingredient by adding hydrogen (or
                removing oxygen).
Replenishing the lipids of the hair or of the top layers of the skin.
Imparting a pleasant freshness to the skin.
Maintaining the skin in good condition.

Acting as lubricants on the skin surface providing the skin with a soft and
                smooth appearance.

Increasing the water content of the top layers of the skin. Humectants are
                primarily hygroscopic agents drawing moisture from the surrounding air.

Enhancing the appearance of dry and/or damaged skin by reducing flaking and
                restoring suppleness.

Retarding the evaporation of water from the skin surface. Occlusives are
                generally lipids which tend to remain on the skin surface and thus increase the water content of skin.
Helping to avoid harmful effects to the skin from external factors.

Enhancing the flow properties of other ingredients without reacting chemically
                with them.

Seeking to achieve an even skin surface by decreasing roughness or
                irregularities.

Dissolving other components of cosmetics. Solvents are usually liquids (aqueous
                and nonaqueous).
Lightening discomfort of the skin or of the scalp.

Applied to other cosmetic components to make them more hydrophilic or
                hydrophobic, or to modify their physical/chemical properties (in some cases, surface modifiers may form
                a covalent bond with substrates).

Helping other ingredients that normally do not mix to dissolve or disperse in
                one another. Surfactants are also called a surface active agents as they lower the surface tension of
                water or reduce the interfacial tension between immiscible components.

Wetting body surfaces, emulsifying or solubilizing oils, and suspending soil
                (generally, such ingredients contribute to the foaming and lathering properties of cleansing products).
Helping distribute an insoluble solid in a liquid phase.

Helping suspensions or dispersions of liquids in a second liquid by reducing the
                surface tension of the substances to be emulsified.
Increasing foaming capacity and/or stabilize foams in general.
Enhancing the water solubility of another surfactant.

Helping another component (solute) to dissolve in a medium in which it is not
                normally soluble.
Darkening the skin with or without exposure to UV.
Producing a feeling of well-being on skin and hair.
Protecting the cosmetic product from the effects of UV-light.

Exclusively or mainly intended to protect the skin and/or hair against certain
                UV radiation by absorbing, reflecting or scattering UV radiation. All authorised UV filters are
                substances in the positive list of Annex VI to the Cosmetics Regulation 1223/2009.
Increasing or decreasing the viscosity (thickness) of cosmetics.
Controlling the pH of cosmetic products.
